snippet: When Viswanathan Anand and Boris Gelfand tied after regulation in the world title match, they were forced to play four rapid games, but that is a fairly new approach to breaking deadlocks.
abstract: Dylan Loeb McClain Chess column observes when defending world champion Viswanathan Anand and his challenger Boris Gelfand tied after regulation in the world title match, they were forced to play four rapid games, but that is a fairly new approach to breaking deadlocks.
lead_paragraph: When Viswanathan Anand and Boris Gelfand tied after regulation in the world title match, they were forced to play four rapid games, but that is a fairly new approach to breaking deadlocks.

headline.print_headline: Determining the Champion: The Rules Keep Changing
headline.seo: Chess: Rules Keep Changing in Title Games
headline.main: Determining the Champion: The Rules Keep Changing
